name: Regionalization
tagline: Reducing Uncertainty in the American Community Survey Using Data-Driven Regionalization
body:
### Introduction
Explanation of problem, regionalization solution

### Regionalization Results
We created four scenarios, Housing, Poverty, Transportation, and a General scenario, each containing a different combination of input variables from the 2008-2012 Five-Year American Community Survey. We then ran the regionalization code for each scenario for every Metropolitan Statistical Area in the United States ([as designated in 2013] (http://www.census.gov/population/metro/data/def.html)). The downloadable results include values for the input variables at the tract level, values of the output variables at the region level, a crosswalk between tracts and regions, shapefiles for the input tracts and output regions, and GeoJSON maps containing the data for the tracts and regions, a data dictionary for the original and derived variables, and a metdata file.

[Results](table.html)

### Publications
Folch, D.C., Arribas-Bel, D., Koschinsky, J., and Spielman, S.E. (in press). Uncertain Uncertainty: Spatial Variation in the Quality of American Community Survey Estimates. Demography

[Spielman, S.E. and Folch, D.F. (2015) Reducing Uncertainty in the American Community Survey through Data-Driven Regionalization. PLOSOne] (http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0115626)

[Spielman, S.E. and Singleton, A. (2015) Studying Neighborhoods with Uncertain Data From the American Community Survey.  Annals of the Association of American Geographers] (http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00045608.2015.1052335)

[Folch, D. and Spielman, S.E. (2014) Identifying Regions based on Flexible User Defined Constraints.  International Journal of Geographic Information Science] (http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/13658816.2013.848986?journalCode=tgis20#.UnG71ZGLDG4)

[Spielman, S.E., Folch, D., Nagle, N. (2014) Patterns and Causes of Uncertainty in the American Community Survey.  Applied Geography] (http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0143622813002518)
